math_problem.A62:
Determine all $ f:R\rightarrow R $ such that
$$ f(xf(y)+y^3)=yf(x)+f(y)^3 $$

math_problem.A119:
Does there exist a finite set $A$ of positive integers of at least two elements and an infinite set $B$ of positive integers, such that any two distinct elements in $A+B$ are coprime, and for any coprime positive integers $m,n$, there exists an element $x$ in $A+B$ satisfying $x\equiv n \pmod m$ ?

Here $A+B=\{a+b|a\in A, b\in B\}$.

{
  "reasoning": "Problem 1: From the functional equation f(xf(y)+y^3)=yf(x)+f(y)^3, first set x=0 to get f(0)=0. Then f(y^3)=f(y)^3 follows. Putting y=1 gives f(1)^3=f(1), so f(1) is 0, 1, or -1. If f(1)=0, the relation f(xf(1)+1)=f(x)+f(1)^3 forces f to be constant, and checking the original equation shows the only constant solution is f(x)=0. For non-constant solutions, we must have f(1)=1 or -1. Taking y=1 in the original equation yields f(xf(1)+1)=f(x)+f(1)^3. The case f(1)=-1 quickly contradicts other instances (e.g., evaluating at small integers), leaving f(1)=1. Then f(x+1)=f(x)+1 for all real x, which implies f(n)=n for all integers n. Using the original equation with y=-1 shows f(-1)=-1 and then implies f(-x)=-f(x) for all x (oddness). Define g(x)=f(x)-x; from f(x+1)=f(x)+1 we get g(x+1)=g(x) (period 1). Combining the functional equation with integer arguments yields relations of the form g(nx+n^3)=n g(x) for integers n, which force g(q)=0 for all rationals q. Using these relations and the periodicity, one shows g must be identically zero, hence f(x)=x for all real x. Together with the constant-zero solution, the only solutions are f(x)=0 and f(x)=x.  \n\nProblem 2: We need a finite A (with at least two positive integers) and an infinite B of positive integers such that (i) all distinct elements of A+B are pairwise coprime, and (ii) for every pair of coprime positive integers (m,n), there is some x in A+B with x≡n (mod m). Fix any finite A with at least two elements, for example A={1,2}. We construct B recursively. Enumerate all pairs (m_i,n_i) of coprime positive integers. At step k, suppose we have already chosen distinct positive integers b_1,...,b_{k-1} so that S_{k-1}=A+{b_1,...,b_{k-1}} has pairwise coprime distinct elements and covers the congruences (m_i,n_i) for i<k. At step k, we choose a new b_k so that: (1) for each a in A, all numbers a+b_k are coprime to every element in S_{k-1}; (2) for all a,a' in A, gcd(a+b_k,a'+b_k)=1; and (3) at least one of the numbers a+b_k (a in A) lies in the congruence class n_k modulo m_k if this class is not yet represented in S_{k-1}. These conditions only exclude finitely many residue classes modulo a finite product of primes, so by the Chinese Remainder Theorem there exist infinitely many positive integers b_k satisfying all of them; we pick one. Proceeding inductively, we build an infinite B={b_k} such that S=A+B has all distinct elements pairwise coprime and hits every residue class n modulo m whenever gcd(m,n)=1. Thus such sets A and B do exist.",
  "answer_1": "All functions f:R->R given by f(x)=0 for all x and f(x)=x for all x",
  "answer_2": "Yes"

output_answer: All functions f:R->R given by f(x)=0 for all x and f(x)=x for all x
